section: Overview and Peritoneum
stem: A nursing student is studying the layers of the digestive tract. Which statement correctly describes the histological organization of the digestive tract from the lumen outward?
rationale: According to the Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 10), the four layers from the lumen outward are: 1. Mucosa, 2. Submucosa, 3. Muscularis externa, and 4. Serosa. The mucosa lines the lumen, followed by submucosa (connective tissue), then muscularis externa (muscle layer), and finally serosa as the outermost layer.

section: Overview and Peritoneum
stem: A patient is diagnosed with peritonitis following a ruptured appendix. The nurse understands that the peritoneum consists of which two layers?

choices.A: Visceral peritoneum covering organs and parietal peritoneum lining the body wall

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 5), the peritoneum consists of the visceral peritoneum (on external surface of most digestive organs) and parietal peritoneum (lines the body wall). The peritoneal cavity is the fluid-filled space between these two layers.

section: Overview and Peritoneum
stem: During an abdominal assessment, the nurse recalls that certain digestive organs are classified as retroperitoneal. Which of the following organs is retroperitoneal?
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 5), retroperitoneal organs are located outside or posterior to the peritoneum and include the pancreas, duodenum, ascending colon, and descending colon. Intraperitoneal organs include the stomach, ileum, and jejunum.

section: Overview and Peritoneum
stem: A nursing instructor asks a student to explain the function of the mesentery. Which response is most accurate?

choices.B: It provides routes for blood vessels, lymphatics, and nerves to digestive organs
choices.D: It forms the outermost layer of the digestive tract

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 5), the mesentery is a double layer of peritoneum that extends from the body wall to digestive organs, providing routes for blood vessels, lymphatics, and nerves. It also holds organs in place and stores fat.

section: Overview and Peritoneum
stem: A patient with liver disease has fluid accumulation in the peritoneal cavity. The nurse understands this space normally contains:
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 5), the peritoneal cavity is a fluid-filled space between the visceral and parietal peritoneum. The fluid lubricates mobile organs, allowing them to move smoothly against each other.

section: Overview and Peritoneum
stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who had a gastrectomy. The surgeon mentions that the stomach was an intraperitoneal organ. This means the stomach is:
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 5), intraperitoneal organs are located within the peritoneum and include the stomach, ileum, and jejunum. Retroperitoneal organs are located outside or posterior to the peritoneum.

section: Overview and Peritoneum
stem: A nursing student is identifying anatomical structures. Which structure is a double layer of peritoneum that extends from the body wall to digestive organs?
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 5), the mesentery is a double layer of peritoneum with layers fused back to back that extends from the body wall to digestive organs. It provides routes for blood vessels, lymphatics, and nerves.

section: Overview and Peritoneum
stem: The nurse is reviewing the anatomy of the abdominal cavity. Which statement correctly distinguishes between intraperitoneal and retroperitoneal organs?

choices.A: The stomach and pancreas are both intraperitoneal
choices.B: The duodenum and ascending colon are retroperitoneal
choices.C: The jejunum and descending colon are both retroperitoneal
choices.D: The liver and pancreas are both intraperitoneal

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 5), retroperitoneal organs include the pancreas, duodenum, ascending colon, and descending colon. Intraperitoneal organs include the stomach, ileum, and jejunum.

section: Overview and Peritoneum
stem: A patient is scheduled for surgery involving the peritoneum. The nurse explains that this serous membrane:

choices.B: Has a visceral layer covering organs and a parietal layer lining the body wall
choices.C: Is a single layer covering all abdominal organs
choices.D: Is found only in the thoracic cavity

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 5), the peritoneum is a serous membrane consisting of visceral peritoneum (on external surface of most digestive organs) and parietal peritoneum (lines the body wall).

section: Overview and Peritoneum
stem: The nurse is teaching a patient about the greater omentum. Which function should the nurse include?

choices.B: Stores fat and holds organs in place

rationale: While not explicitly detailed in the text regarding the omentum specifically, Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 5) states that mesentery (which includes omenta) holds organs in place and stores fat. The greater omentum is a specific type of mesentery with these functions. Questions 11-20: Histological Organization

section: Histological Organization
stem: A biopsy of the esophageal lining is obtained from a patient with Barrett's esophagus. Normally, the epithelium of the esophagus is:
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 10), the mouth, esophagus, and anus are made up of stratified squamous epithelium, while most of the rest of the tract has simple columnar epithelium.

section: Histological Organization
stem: The nurse is reviewing the layers of the digestive tract. Which layer contains blood vessels, lymphatic vessels, and lymphoid follicles?
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 10), the submucosa consists of connective tissue, blood and lymphatic vessels, lymphoid follicles, and nerve plexus.

section: Histological Organization
stem: A patient has a condition affecting the muscularis externa. The nurse understands that this layer is responsible for:
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 10), the muscularis externa is the muscle layer responsible for movement. It contains inner circular muscle and outer longitudinal layers, with circular layer thickening in some areas to form sphincters.

section: Histological Organization
stem: The nurse is educating a patient about how the digestive tract protects itself from acid. Which layer of the stomach contains mucus-secreting cells?
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 10), the mucosa contains epithelium with mucus-secreting cells in most of the tract. In the stomach specifically, mucous neck cells secrete thin mucus.

section: Histological Organization
stem: A nursing student identifies that the outermost layer of the intraperitoneal organs is the:
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 10), the serosa is the outermost layer and is the visceral peritoneum. It is replaced by fibrous adventitia in the esophagus to bind it to surrounding tissues.

section: Histological Organization
stem: The nurse is assessing a patient with a disorder affecting the lamina propria. This structure is part of which layer?
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 10), the mucosa is made up of three sublayers: epithelium, lamina propria (loose areolar connective tissue), and muscularis mucosae.

section: Histological Organization
stem: A patient has inflammation of the digestive tract affecting the muscularis mucosae. This thin muscle layer is found in the:
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 10), the mucosa consists of three sublayers: epithelium, lamina propria, and muscularis mucosae.

section: Histological Organization
stem: The nurse understands that sphincters in the digestive tract are formed by thickening of which layer?

choices.C: Inner circular layer of muscularis externa
choices.D: Outer longitudinal layer of muscularis externa

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 10), the circular layer of the muscularis externa thickens in some areas to form sphincters.

section: Histological Organization
stem: A patient has a condition affecting the adventitia of the esophagus. The nurse knows that this structure:

choices.B: Binds the esophagus to surrounding tissues

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 10), the serosa is replaced by fibrous adventitia in the esophagus to bind the esophagus to surrounding tissues.

section: Histological Organization
stem: The nurse is reviewing the histology of the digestive tract. Which statement about the epithelial lining is correct?

choices.A: The entire digestive tract is lined by simple columnar epithelium
choices.B: The mouth and esophagus are lined by stratified squamous epithelium
choices.C: The stomach is lined by stratified squamous epithelium
choices.D: The small intestine is lined by transitional epithelium

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 10), the mouth, esophagus, and anus are lined by stratified squamous epithelium. Most of the rest of the tract has simple columnar epithelium. Questions 21-30: Oral Cavity, Salivary Glands, and Teeth

section: Oral Cavity, Salivary Glands, and Teeth
stem: A patient presents with swelling anterior to the ear. The nurse suspects inflammation of which salivary gland?
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 17), the parotid gland is located anterior to the ear and external to the masseter muscle. Its duct opens into the oral vestibule next to the second upper molar.

section: Oral Cavity, Salivary Glands, and Teeth
stem: The nurse is assessing a patient's tongue and notes a V-shaped row of papillae in the posterior region. These are most likely:
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 14), vallate (circumvallate) papillae are 8-12 in number and form a V-shaped row in the back of the tongue.

section: Oral Cavity, Salivary Glands, and Teeth
stem: A patient complains of dry mouth (xerostomia) during stressful situations. The nurse understands this is likely due to:

choices.D: Overactive salivary nuclei in the brain stem

rationale: According to Physiology Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 10), sympathetic stimulation (T1-T3) produces viscous saliva, causing dry mouth during stress. Parasympathetic stimulation initiates and maintains watery saliva secretion.

section: Oral Cavity, Salivary Glands, and Teeth
stem: The nurse is providing oral care to a patient and notices the lingual frenulum. This structure:

choices.A: Separates the oral cavity from the nasal cavity
choices.B: Attaches the tongue to the floor of the mouth
choices.C: Forms the V-shaped row of papillae
choices.D: Marks the division between the body and root of the tongue

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 14), the lingual frenulum is the attachment of the tongue to the floor of the mouth.

section: Oral Cavity, Salivary Glands, and Teeth
stem: A dental hygienist is teaching a patient about tooth development. The primary (deciduous) dental formula indicates how many teeth?
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 20), the primary dental formula is 2I, 1C, 2M (upper jaw) × 2 = 20 teeth. The permanent formula shows 32 teeth.

section: Oral Cavity, Salivary Glands, and Teeth
stem: A patient has lost the sense of taste following a viral infection. The nurse recalls that which type of papillae do NOT contain taste buds?
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 14), filiform papillae give roughness to provide friction but do NOT contain taste buds. Fungiform, vallate, and foliate papillae do contain taste buds.

section: Oral Cavity, Salivary Glands, and Teeth
stem: The nurse is assessing a patient with a suspected salivary duct obstruction. The submandibular gland duct opens:

choices.A: Next to the second upper molar
choices.B: At the base of the lingual frenulum
choices.C: Via 10-12 ducts into the floor of the mouth

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 17), the submandibular gland duct opens at the base of the lingual frenulum. The parotid duct opens next to the second upper molar, and the sublingual gland opens via 10-12 ducts into the floor of the mouth.

section: Oral Cavity, Salivary Glands, and Teeth
stem: A patient has inflammation of the lingual tonsil. The nurse understands this structure is located:

choices.A: On the body of the tongue
choices.B: In the root of the tongue

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 14), the root of the tongue (posterior third residing in the oropharynx) is bumpy because of the lingual tonsil, which lies deep to its mucosa.

section: Oral Cavity, Salivary Glands, and Teeth
stem: The nurse is teaching a patient about the functions of saliva. Which component of saliva provides protection against bacteria?
rationale: According to Physiology Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 9), saliva provides protection through lysozyme (prevents bacterial growth/tooth decay), IgA, cyanide, and defensins. Lubrication is provided by mucus, and digestion by amylase and lipase.

section: Oral Cavity, Salivary Glands, and Teeth
stem: A patient has a tumor affecting the intrinsic muscles of the tongue. This will most likely affect the ability to:

choices.A: Move the tongue from side to side
choices.B: Change the shape of the tongue
choices.C: Attach the tongue to the floor of the mouth
choices.D: Alter the position of the tongue

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 13), intrinsic muscles change the shape of the tongue, while extrinsic muscles alter the tongue's position. Questions 31-40: Pharynx and Esophagus

section: Pharynx and Esophagus
stem: The nurse is reviewing the anatomy of the pharynx. Which statement correctly describes its structure and function?

choices.A: It allows passage of food only
choices.B: It is lined by simple columnar epithelium
choices.C: It allows passage of food, fluids, and air

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 22), the pharynx allows passage of food, fluids, and air. It is lined by stratified squamous epithelium with mucus-producing glands and has inner longitudinal and outer constrictor muscle layers.

section: Pharynx and Esophagus
stem: A patient with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) asks about the structure that normally prevents stomach acid from entering the esophagus. The nurse explains that this is the:
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 23), the gastroesophageal (cardiac) sphincter surrounds the cardinal orifice and keeps the orifice closed when food is not being swallowed. Physiology Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 14) notes that when this sphincter fails, GERD occurs.

section: Pharynx and Esophagus
stem: A nursing student is studying the layers of the esophageal muscularis externa. Which statement is correct?

choices.A: It contains only smooth muscle throughout
choices.B: It contains only skeletal muscle throughout
choices.C: It contains skeletal muscle superiorly, mixed in the middle, and smooth muscle inferiorly
choices.D: It contains smooth muscle superiorly and skeletal muscle inferiorly

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 23), the muscularis externa of the esophagus contains skeletal muscle superiorly, mixed muscle in the middle, and smooth muscle inferiorly.

section: Pharynx and Esophagus
stem: The nurse is caring for a patient with a hiatal hernia. The esophagus pierces the diaphragm at which structure?
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 23), the esophagus pierces the diaphragm at the esophageal hiatus.

section: Pharynx and Esophagus
stem: A patient reports heartburn after meals. The nurse explains that the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) is a physiological sphincter that:

choices.A: Is composed of thick circular smooth muscle only
choices.B: Relaxes with the arrival of peristaltic waves

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 24), the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) is a physiological sphincter that relaxes with the arrival of peristaltic waves.

section: Pharynx and Esophagus
stem: The nurse is reviewing the blood supply to the esophagus. In the thorax, the esophagus is related to which structures?

choices.C: Superior vena cava and pulmonary artery

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 24), in the thorax, the esophagus passes through the posterior mediastinum and is related to the left atrium and descending aorta.

section: Pharynx and Esophagus
stem: A patient is about to undergo an endoscopy. The nurse knows that at the gastroesophageal junction, the epithelial lining changes from:
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 23), the esophageal mucosa contains stratified squamous epithelium, which changes to simple columnar at the stomach.

section: Pharynx and Esophagus
stem: The nurse is teaching about esophageal glands. These glands are located in which layer and serve what function?
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 25), the esophagus has mucus-secreting glands in the submucosa aiding lubrication and movement.

section: Pharynx and Esophagus
stem: A patient has difficulty swallowing (dysphagia). The nurse recalls that the esophagus begins at which vertebral level?
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 24), the esophagus begins at cervical vertebral level 6 and lies posterior to the trachea.

section: Pharynx and Esophagus
stem: The nurse is caring for a patient with achalasia, a condition where the LES fails to relax. Normally, the esophagus:

choices.B: Is collapsed when not involved in food propulsion

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 23), the esophagus is a flat muscular tube that is collapsed when not involved in food propulsion. Questions 41-50: Stomach

section: Stomach
stem: A patient is scheduled for a gastric resection. The surgeon explains that the stomach can expand significantly. What is the approximate volume of an empty stomach and its maximum capacity?
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 27), an empty stomach has approximately 50 ml volume but can expand to 4 L.

section: Stomach
stem: During a gastric surgery, the surgeon identifies the region surrounding the cardinal orifice. This is the:
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 27), the cardia is the region that surrounds the cardial orifice.

section: Stomach
stem: A patient with peptic ulcer disease has overactive parietal cells. The nurse understands that these cells secrete:
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 30), parietal cells secrete hydrochloric acid (pH 1.5–3.5) and intrinsic factor (required for absorption of vitamin B12 in the small intestine).

section: Stomach
stem: The nurse is reviewing gastric gland histology. Which cells secrete pepsinogen, which is activated to pepsin by HCl?
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 30), chief cells secrete pepsinogen, which is activated to pepsin by HCl. Mucous neck cells secrete thin mucus, parietal cells secrete HCl and intrinsic factor, and enteroendocrine cells secrete gastrin.

section: Stomach
stem: A patient's gastric analysis reveals low intrinsic factor production. The nurse anticipates that this patient may develop:
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 30), parietal cells secrete intrinsic factor, which is required for absorption of vitamin B12 in the small intestine. Deficiency of intrinsic factor leads to vitamin B12 deficiency anemia (pernicious anemia).

section: Stomach
stem: The nurse is assessing a patient with a gastric tumor that has destroyed gastrin-secreting cells. Which cells are most likely affected?
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 30), enteroendocrine cells secrete gastrin. Gastrin stimulates HCl release from parietal cells.

section: Stomach
stem: A patient asks how the stomach protects itself from its own acid. The nurse explains that mucous neck cells secrete:
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 30), mucous neck cells secrete thin mucus. (Note: Surface mucous cells secrete thick, alkaline mucus for protection.)

section: Stomach
stem: The nurse is reviewing the layers of the stomach's muscularis externa. Unlike other parts of the GI tract, the stomach has:

choices.C: Three muscle layers (longitudinal, circular, and oblique)

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 30), the muscularis externa of the stomach has three layers: circular, longitudinal, and an extra third layer called the oblique layer.

section: Stomach
stem: A patient who had a gastrectomy asks about the rugae. The nurse explains that these are:

choices.B: Folds in the stomach mucosa that disappear when the stomach is full

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 27), when empty, the stomach mucosa forms many folds called rugae. These flatten as the stomach expands.

section: Stomach
stem: The nurse is caring for a patient with a pyloric obstruction. The pyloric sphincter is located between the:
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 27), the pyloric part terminates in the pyloric sphincter, which controls emptying of stomach contents into the duodenum. Questions 51-60: Small Intestine

section: Small Intestine
stem: A nursing student is studying the subdivisions of the small intestine. Which statement correctly describes the duodenum?

choices.B: It is mostly retroperitoneal and 25 cm long
choices.C: It is 3.6 m long and attached by mesentery
choices.D: It joins the large intestine at the ileocecal valve

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 32), the duodenum is mostly retroperitoneal, approximately 25.0 cm long, and curves around the head of the pancreas.

section: Small Intestine
stem: The nurse is teaching a patient about nutrient absorption. Which modification of the small intestine increases surface area by approximately 600 times?

choices.D: Circular folds, villi, and microvilli together

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 35), the small intestine's surface area is increased 600 times to 200 m² by three modifications: circular folds, villi, and microvilli.

section: Small Intestine
stem: A patient has a condition affecting the lacteals in the small intestine. The nurse understands that these structures are:

choices.A: Blood capillaries that absorb amino acids
choices.B: Lymphatic capillaries that absorb fatty acids

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 35), villi contain a core with a blood capillary and a lymphatic capillary called a lacteal. Fatty acids are absorbed into the lacteal and transported via the lymphatic system.

section: Small Intestine
stem: The nurse is reviewing the blood supply to the small intestine. The superior mesenteric artery supplies blood to the:
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 32), the small intestine receives blood from the superior mesenteric artery. Veins drain into superior mesenteric veins, then into the hepatic portal vein.

section: Small Intestine
stem: A patient has a bacterial overgrowth in the distal small intestine. The nurse recalls that Peyer's patches, which protect against microorganisms, are most numerous in the:
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 41), Peyer's patches (aggregated lymphoid nodules) are found in great numbers in the distal part of the small intestine (ileum), where bacterial numbers increase.

section: Small Intestine
stem: The nurse is educating a patient about the function of intestinal crypts. These structures:

choices.B: Produce intestinal juice and contain stem cells for epithelial renewal

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 40), intestinal crypts produce intestinal juice and contain stem cells that continuously divide to produce other cell types. Villus epithelium is renewed every 2-4 days.

section: Small Intestine
stem: A patient has a deficiency in brush border enzymes. The nurse understands that these enzymes are located on the:
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 35), microvilli are cytoplasmic extensions of mucosal cells that give a fuzzy appearance called the brush border. They contain membrane-bound brush border enzymes used for final carbohydrate and protein digestion.

section: Small Intestine
stem: The nurse is reviewing the functions of different cell types in the small intestine. Which cells secrete antimicrobial agents such as defensins and lysozyme?
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 40), Paneth cells secrete antimicrobial agents (defensins and lysozyme) that can destroy bacteria.

section: Small Intestine
stem: A patient has a duodenal ulcer. The nurse understands that the duodenal (Brunner's) glands secrete:

choices.B: Alkaline mucus to neutralize acidic chyme

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 41), duodenal glands of the duodenum secrete alkaline mucus to neutralize acidic chyme entering from the stomach.

section: Small Intestine
stem: The nurse is comparing the jejunum and ileum. Which statement correctly differentiates these two segments?

choices.A: The jejunum has more Peyer's patches than the ileum
choices.B: The ileum has more circular folds than the jejunum
choices.C: The jejunum has larger and more numerous plicae circularis than the ileum
choices.D: The ileum is wider and thicker-walled than the jejunum

rationale: According to Physiology of Digestive System.pdf (Page 38), the jejunum has larger and more numerous plicae circularis, longer and more numerous villi, and absent Peyer's patches, while the ileum has smaller and less numerous plicae circularis, shorter and less numerous villi, and present Peyer's patches. Questions 61-70: Large Intestine, Liver, Gallbladder, and Pancreas

section: Large Intestine, Liver, Gallbladder, and Pancreas
stem: The nurse is assessing a patient with appendicitis. The appendix is located near the:
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 43), the appendix is attached to the cecum, the first part of the large intestine. It contains masses of lymphoid tissue.

section: Large Intestine, Liver, Gallbladder, and Pancreas
stem: A patient has a condition affecting the teniae coli. The nurse understands that these structures are:

choices.B: Three bands of longitudinal smooth muscle in the muscularis of the colon
choices.C: Pocket-like sacs caused by muscle tone

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 42), the large intestine has three unique features: teniae coli (three bands of longitudinal smooth muscle in muscularis), haustra (pocketlike sacs caused by tone of teniae coli), and epiploic appendages (fat-filled pouches of visceral peritoneum).

section: Large Intestine, Liver, Gallbladder, and Pancreas
stem: The nurse is teaching a patient about defecation. The external anal sphincter is composed of:
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 44), the anus has two sphincters: the internal anal sphincter (smooth muscle) and the external anal sphincter (skeletal muscle). Physiology of Digestive System.pdf (Page 29) notes that the external anal sphincter is voluntary.

section: Large Intestine, Liver, Gallbladder, and Pancreas
stem: A patient with cirrhosis has an enlarged liver. The nurse recalls that the liver is the largest gland in the body and consists of how many primary lobes?

choices.B: Three lobes: right, left, and caudate
choices.C: Four lobes: right, left, caudate, and quadrate
choices.D: Five lobes: right, left, caudate, quadrate, and round

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 46), the liver consists of four primary lobes: right, left, caudate, and quadrate.

section: Large Intestine, Liver, Gallbladder, and Pancreas
stem: The nurse is reviewing the microscopic anatomy of the liver. Which structures are found in the portal triad at each corner of a liver lobule?

choices.A: Central vein, bile duct, and lymphatic vessel
choices.B: Branch of hepatic artery, branch of hepatic portal vein, and bile duct
choices.C: Hepatic artery, hepatic vein, and hepatic duct
choices.D: Kupffer cells, sinusoids, and central vein

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 50), the portal triad in each corner of a liver lobule contains a branch of the hepatic artery (supplies oxygen), a branch of the hepatic portal vein (brings nutrient-rich blood from intestine), and a bile duct (receives bile from bile canaliculi).

section: Large Intestine, Liver, Gallbladder, and Pancreas
stem: A patient has a gallbladder attack after eating a fatty meal. The nurse understands that the gallbladder functions to:
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 53), the gallbladder is a thin-walled muscular sac on the ventral surface of the liver that functions to store and concentrate bile by absorbing water and ions. Muscular contractions release bile via the cystic duct.

section: Large Intestine, Liver, Gallbladder, and Pancreas
stem: The nurse is caring for a patient with pancreatitis. The pancreas has both exocrine and endocrine functions. The exocrine function involves:

choices.B: Production of pancreatic juice containing digestive enzymes

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 55), the exocrine function of the pancreas is to produce pancreatic juice. Acini (clusters of secretory cells) produce zymogen granules containing proenzymes, and duct cells produce water and bicarbonate. The endocrine function involves secretion of insulin and glucagon.

section: Large Intestine, Liver, Gallbladder, and Pancreas
stem: A patient has a bile duct obstruction. Which structure is formed by the union of the common hepatic duct and the cystic duct?
rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 51), the common hepatic duct (CHD) is joined by the cystic duct to form the common bile duct (CBD). The CBD and pancreatic duct unite in the wall of the duodenum.

section: Large Intestine, Liver, Gallbladder, and Pancreas
stem: The nurse is reviewing the blood supply to the liver. Which vessels bring blood to the liver?

choices.B: Hepatic artery and hepatic portal vein

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 50), blood from both the hepatic portal vein (nutrient-rich blood from intestine) and the hepatic artery proper (oxygenated blood) percolates from triad regions through sinusoids and empties into the central vein.

section: Large Intestine, Liver, Gallbladder, and Pancreas
stem: A patient has a condition affecting Kupffer cells in the liver. The nurse understands that these cells function to:

choices.B: Remove debris and old red blood cells

rationale: According to Anatomy of Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 50), hepatic macrophages (Kupffer cells) in the liver sinusoids remove debris and old red blood cells. Questions 71-80: Physiology of Digestion and Absorption

section: Physiology of Digestion and Absorption
stem: The nurse is teaching a patient about the regulation of gastric secretion. Which phase is triggered by the sight, smell, or thought of food?
rationale: According to Physiology Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 18), the cephalic phase is triggered by the smell, taste, sight, or thought of food before food enters the stomach. It is mediated by the vagus nerve and gets the stomach ready, lasting a few minutes.

section: Physiology of Digestion and Absorption
stem: A patient asks why they feel nauseous when dizzy. The nurse explains that vomiting is a complex reflex coordinated in the:
rationale: According to Physiology Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 19), vomiting is a complex reflex coordinated in the brain stem. Stimuli include stomach distension, seasickness or dizziness, pain, increased intracranial pressure, noxious chemicals, toxins, and drugs.

section: Physiology of Digestion and Absorption
stem: The nurse is reviewing the function of bile salts. Which statement accurately describes their role in digestion?

choices.B: They emulsify fats, breaking them into smaller droplets

rationale: According to Physiology Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 29), bile salts emulsify fat, which means they physically break down large fat globules into smaller droplets. This increases surface area for pancreatic lipase action. Chemical digestion of fats is performed by lipase.

section: Physiology of Digestion and Absorption
stem: A patient with liver disease has prolonged bleeding. The nurse recalls that vitamin K, which is essential for synthesis of clotting factors, is:
rationale: According to Physiology Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 27), resident bacteria (bacterial flora) in the large intestine break down indigestible carbohydrates and synthesize some B-complex vitamins and significant amounts of vitamin K. Vitamin K is essential for the synthesis of some blood clotting factors in the liver.

section: Physiology of Digestion and Absorption
stem: The nurse is teaching about carbohydrate digestion. Which enzyme is responsible for breaking down carbohydrates into disaccharides?
rationale: According to Physiology Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 34), pancreatic amylase breaks down carbohydrates into disaccharides. Pancreatic lipase breaks down lipids, proteases break down proteins, and nucleases break down nucleic acids.

section: Physiology of Digestion and Absorption
stem: A patient has a condition affecting the brush border enzymes. The nurse understands that aminopeptidase and dipeptidase are involved in digesting:
rationale: According to Physiology Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 24), brush border enzymes include carboxypeptidase (removes amino acids from carboxyl end), aminopeptidase (removes amino acids from amino end), and dipeptidase (splits dipeptides into separate amino acids). These enzymes are involved in protein digestion.

section: Physiology of Digestion and Absorption
stem: The nurse is reviewing fat absorption. After fatty acids and monoglycerides are absorbed into epithelial cells, they are repackaged into:
rationale: According to Physiology Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 42), fatty acids and monoglycerides leave micelles and diffuse into epithelial cells. There they are recombined and packaged with other fatty substances and proteins to form chylomicrons. Chylomicrons are extruded from epithelial cells by exocytosis and enter lacteals.

section: Physiology of Digestion and Absorption
stem: A patient with pancreatic insufficiency has difficulty digesting fats. The nurse understands that pancreatic lipase requires which substance for optimal function?
rationale: According to Physiology Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 42), bile salts in the duodenum emulsify large fat globules, physically breaking them into smaller fat droplets. Digestion of fat by pancreatic lipase then yields free fatty acids and monoglycerides. Bile salts are essential for emulsification, which increases surface area for lipase action.

section: Physiology of Digestion and Absorption
stem: The nurse is educating a patient about the enteric nervous system (ENS). Which statement accurately describes this system?

choices.A: It is part of the central nervous system
choices.B: It is a self-contained (intrinsic) nervous system that regulates digestive activities
choices.C: It only controls blood flow to the digestive tract

rationale: According to Physiology Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 5), the enteric nervous system (ENS) is self-contained (intrinsic) and regulates the activities of the digestive system. It controls motility including peristalsis and segmentation.

section: Physiology of Digestion and Absorption
stem: A patient with a hormone-secreting tumor has elevated cholecystokinin (CCK) levels. The nurse expects which effects?

choices.A: Decreased pancreatic enzyme secretion and gallbladder relaxation
choices.B: Increased output of enzyme-rich pancreatic juice and gallbladder contraction
choices.D: Decreased bile output from the liver

rationale: According to Physiology Digestive system 1.pdf (Page 7), cholecystokinin (CCK) is produced by the duodenal mucosa in response to fatty chyme. It increases output of enzyme-rich pancreatic juice and stimulates the gallbladder to contract and expel stored bile. It also inhibits stomach secretory activity. Answer Key Summary Q# Answer Q# Answer Q# Answer Q# Answer 1 B 21 B 41 B 61 C 2 A 22 C 42 C 62 B 3 C 23 B 43 B 63 B 4 B 24 B 44 B 64 C 5 B 25 C 45 B 65 B 6 B 26 D 46 C 66 B 7 B 27 B 47 B 67 B 8 B 28 B 48 C 68 B 9 B 29 C 49 B 69 B 10 B 30 B 50 B 70 B 11 B 31 C 51 B 71 C 12 B 32 C 52 D 72 C 13 C 33 C 53 B 73 B 14 D 34 B 54 B 74 B 15 B 35 B 55 C 75 C 16 A 36 B 56 B 76 B 17 B 37 B 57 B 77 B 18 C 38 B 58 C 78 B 19 B 39 B 59 B 79 B 20 B 40 B 60 C 80 B

section: Part 1: General Organization, Peritoneum, and Histology
stem: A patient is scheduled for an exploratory laparotomy. The surgeon explains that they will be accessing the "alimentary canal." Which organ would the nurse expect to be included in this specific category?
rationale: The alimentary canal is the continuous muscular tube from mouth to anus, including the mouth, pharynx, esophagus, stomach, small intestine, large intestine, and anus. Liver, pancreas, and gallbladder are accessory organs.

section: Part 1: General Organization, Peritoneum, and Histology
stem: A student nurse is reviewing the histological layers of the GI tract. Which layer is correctly matched with its primary function?

choices.A: Mucosa: Responsible for peristalsis and segmentation.
choices.B: Submucosa: Contains blood vessels, lymphatic follicles, and nerve plexuses.
choices.C: Muscularis externa: Outermost layer that anchors the esophagus to surrounding structures.
choices.D: Serosa: The layer in direct contact with the lumen, secreting mucus.

rationale: The submucosa consists of connective tissue, blood/lymphatic vessels, and nerve plexuses. The muscularis externa is for movement, and the mucosa lines the lumen.

section: Part 1: General Organization, Peritoneum, and Histology
stem: During a physical exam, a patient reports pain in the "retroperitoneal space." Based on anatomical organization, which organ could be the source of this pain?
rationale: The pancreas is a retroperitoneal organ. The stomach, jejunum, and ileum are intraperitoneal.

section: Part 1: General Organization, Peritoneum, and Histology
stem: A patient is diagnosed with an infection in the peritoneal cavity. The nurse knows that this "potential space" is located between which two structures?

choices.B: The visceral peritoneum and the parietal peritoneum.
choices.C: The greater omentum and the lesser omentum.
choices.D: The circular and longitudinal muscle layers.

rationale: The peritoneal cavity is the fluid-filled space between the visceral peritoneum (on organ surfaces) and parietal peritoneum (lining the body wall).

section: Part 1: General Organization, Peritoneum, and Histology
stem: A patient has a blockage in the mesentery. The nurse understands that this condition is critical because the mesentery provides which essential function?

choices.B: Routes for blood vessels, lymphatics, and nerves to reach the organs.
choices.C: Mechanical breakdown of plant cell walls.
choices.D: Neutralization of acidic chyme using bicarbonate.

rationale: Mesentery is a double layer of peritoneum that provides routes for blood vessels, lymphatics, and nerves, and holds organs in place.

section: Part 1: General Organization, Peritoneum, and Histology
stem: A biopsy of a patient’s esophagus shows a change from stratified squamous epithelium to simple columnar epithelium. At which anatomical junction was this biopsy most likely taken?

choices.A: Junction of the pharynx and esophagus.
choices.B: Junction of the esophagus and stomach.
choices.C: Junction of the stomach and duodenum.
choices.D: Junction of the ileum and cecum.

rationale: The esophageal mucosa contains stratified squamous epithelium which changes to simple columnar at the stomach.

section: Part 1: General Organization, Peritoneum, and Histology
stem: While reviewing the histology of the digestive tract, the nurse identifies the "Myenteric nerve plexus." Where is this plexus located?

choices.A: Within the lamina propria of the mucosa.
choices.B: Between the circular and longitudinal layers of the muscularis externa.
choices.C: In the fibrous adventitia of the esophagus.

rationale: The myenteric nerve plexus is located between the circular and longitudinal muscle layers of the muscularis externa and controls GI motility.

section: Part 1: General Organization, Peritoneum, and Histology
stem: A patient is admitted with a rupture of the "serosa" in the abdominal cavity. Which histological layer does this correspond to?

choices.A: The innermost lining of the lumen.
choices.B: The layer containing the submucosal nerve plexus.
choices.C: The outermost layer of the intraperitoneal organs.
choices.D: The layer responsible for forming sphincters.

rationale: The serosa is the outermost layer of the alimentary canal in the abdominal cavity.

section: Part 1: General Organization, Peritoneum, and Histology
stem: A nurse is explaining the anatomy of the peritoneum to a student. Which term describes the structure that anchors the liver to the stomach?
rationale: The lesser omentum anchors the liver to the stomach.

section: Part 1: General Organization, Peritoneum, and Histology
stem: A patient presents with a defect in the "Muscularis mucosae." In which major histological layer is this sublayer found?
rationale: The mucosa is made up of three sublayers: epithelium, lamina propria, and muscularis mucosae. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Part 2: Oral Cavity, Pharynx, and Esophagus

section: Part 2: Oral Cavity, Pharynx, and Esophagus
stem: A 5-year-old child is in the clinic for a dental check-up. The nurse notes the child has 20 teeth. Which dental formula represents this primary (deciduous) dentition?
rationale: The primary dental formula is 2 Incisors, 1 Canine, 2 Molars per quadrant, totaling 20 teeth.

section: Part 2: Oral Cavity, Pharynx, and Esophagus
stem: A patient reports a loss of taste on the lateral aspects of the posterior tongue. Which type of papillae is most likely involved?
rationale: Foliate papillae are located on the lateral aspects of the posterior tongue.

section: Part 2: Oral Cavity, Pharynx, and Esophagus
stem: During an oral examination, the nurse asks the patient to stick out their tongue to check its position. Which muscles are primarily responsible for altering the tongue’s position?
rationale: Extrinsic muscles alter the tongue’s position; intrinsic muscles change its shape.

section: Part 2: Oral Cavity, Pharynx, and Esophagus
stem: A patient has a blockage in the parotid duct. Where should the nurse inspect for the opening of this duct?

choices.A: At the base of the lingual frenulum.
choices.B: Under the tongue in the floor of the mouth.
choices.C: In the oral vestibule next to the second upper molar.
choices.D: Posterior to the vallate papillae on the tongue.

rationale: The parotid duct opens into the oral vestibule next to the second upper molar.

section: Part 2: Oral Cavity, Pharynx, and Esophagus
stem: A patient is diagnosed with "Xerostomia" (dry mouth) due to stress. The nurse understands this is caused by which physiological mechanism?

choices.A: Parasympathetic stimulation of cranial nerves VII and IX.
choices.C: Increased release of lysozyme and IgA.
choices.D: Relaxation of the upper esophageal sphincter.

rationale: Sympathetic stimulation (T1-T3) produces viscous saliva, leading to a dry mouth feeling during stress.

section: Part 2: Oral Cavity, Pharynx, and Esophagus
stem: During the "Buccal phase" of swallowing, which event occurs?

choices.A: The uvula and larynx rise to block respiratory passages.
choices.B: The tongue presses against the hard palate, forcing the bolus into the oropharynx.
choices.D: Peristalsis moves the food through the esophagus.

rationale: The buccal phase is voluntary; the tongue presses against the hard palate to move the bolus.

section: Part 2: Oral Cavity, Pharynx, and Esophagus
stem: A patient with GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease) complains of "heartburn." Which structure is failing to maintain its physiological function?
rationale: Heartburn occurs when gastric acid regurgitates into the esophagus due to a failure of the gastroesophageal (cardiac) sphincter.

section: Part 2: Oral Cavity, Pharynx, and Esophagus
stem: A nurse is reviewing a patient’s chest X-ray and notes the esophagus passing through the diaphragm. Which anatomical landmark does this represent?
rationale: The esophagus pierces the diaphragm at the esophageal hiatus.

section: Part 2: Oral Cavity, Pharynx, and Esophagus
stem: A patient is having difficulty swallowing. The nurse knows the esophagus is a flat muscular tube that is usually collapsed. What is the primary motility pattern that moves food through the esophagus?
rationale: Motility in the esophagus is by peristalsis (progressive waves of muscle contraction).

section: Part 2: Oral Cavity, Pharynx, and Esophagus
stem: A patient has a tumor in the "oropharynx." Which histological lining should the nurse expect to find in this area?
rationale: The pharynx (including oropharynx) is lined by stratified squamous epithelium with mucus-producing glands. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Part 3: The Stomach

section: Part 3: The Stomach
stem: A patient presents with pernicious anemia. The nurse understands this may be due to the loss of which cell type in the gastric glands?
rationale: Parietal cells secrete intrinsic factor, which is required for the absorption of vitamin B12 in the small intestine.

section: Part 3: The Stomach
stem: A student is identifying the regions of the stomach on a model. Which region is correctly described as the dome-shaped area beneath the diaphragm?
rationale: The fundus is the dome-shaped region beneath the diaphragm.

section: Part 3: The Stomach
stem: A patient is taking a medication that inhibits the "G cells" of the stomach. What would be the primary effect on digestion?

choices.A: Decreased secretion of gastrin and HCl.
choices.C: Reduced secretion of thin, acidic mucus.

rationale: G cells (enteroendocrine cells) secrete gastrin, which stimulates HCl release.

section: Part 3: The Stomach
stem: During the "Gastric phase" of secretion, which stimulus leads to the highest release of HCl?

choices.A: The sight or thought of food.
choices.B: Distention of the stomach and a rise in pH.
choices.C: The presence of acidic chyme in the duodenum.
choices.D: Stimulation by the sympathetic nervous system.

rationale: The gastric phase is triggered by distention, food, and rising pH, lasting 3–4 hours.

section: Part 3: The Stomach
stem: A nurse explains to a patient that the stomach has an "extra" layer of muscle not found in other GI organs. What is this layer?
rationale: The stomach’s muscularis externa has three layers: circular, longitudinal, and an extra oblique layer.

section: Part 3: The Stomach
stem: In the mechanism of HCl secretion, what is the "alkaline tide"?

choices.A: The pump of H+ into the stomach lumen.
choices.B: The movement of bicarbonate (HCO3-) out of the parietal cell into the blood.
choices.C: The diffusion of CO2 into the parietal cell.
choices.D: The activation of pepsinogen by HCl.

rationale: As parietal cells pump H+ into the lumen, HCO3- is exported to the blood, creating an alkaline tide.

section: Part 3: The Stomach
stem: A patient’s stomach is empty. The nurse expects to see which anatomical feature upon endoscopy?
rationale: When empty, the stomach mucosa forms many folds called rugae.

section: Part 3: The Stomach
stem: Which enzyme is responsible for the chemical digestion of proteins in the stomach?
rationale: Chief cells secrete pepsinogen, which is activated to pepsin by HCl for protein digestion.

section: Part 3: The Stomach
stem: A patient is experiencing "retropulsion" in the stomach. The nurse knows this refers to:

choices.A: The delivery of chyme into the duodenum.
choices.B: The movement of the bolus from the fundus to the pylorus.
choices.C: The forcing of chyme backward into the stomach to facilitate grinding.
choices.D: The relaxation of the gastroesophageal sphincter.

rationale: Retropulsion occurs when the pyloric end forces material backward for further mixing/grinding.

section: Part 3: The Stomach
stem: What is the typical pH range of gastric juice produced by parietal cells?
rationale: Parietal cells secrete HCl, creating a pH of 1.5–3.5. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Part 4: Small Intestine and Accessory Organs

section: Part 4: Small Intestine and Accessory Organs
stem: A patient has a tumor in the "Duodenum." The nurse notes that this organ is mostly:

choices.C: Located in the left iliac region

rationale: The duodenum is mostly retroperitoneal and curves around the head of the pancreas.

section: Part 4: Small Intestine and Accessory Organs
stem: Which structural modification of the small intestine is responsible for the "brush border"?
rationale: Microvilli are cytoplasmic extensions that give a fuzzy "brush border" appearance and contain enzymes.

section: Part 4: Small Intestine and Accessory Organs
stem: A patient is unable to digest fats effectively. Which hormone, released by the duodenal mucosa, stimulates the gallbladder to contract and the hepatopancreatic sphincter to relax?
rationale: CCK stimulates gallbladder contraction and relaxes the hepatopancreatic sphincter.

section: Part 4: Small Intestine and Accessory Organs
stem: A nurse is reviewing a pathology report of a biopsy from the "distal part of the small intestine." The presence of "Peyer’s patches" confirms the biopsy is from which section?
rationale: Peyer’s patches are aggregated lymphoid nodules found in great numbers in the distal part (ileum) of the small intestine.

section: Part 4: Small Intestine and Accessory Organs
stem: A patient has a blockage in the "Lacteal" of the villi. Which nutrient absorption will be most affected?
rationale: Lacteals are lymphatic capillaries in the villi that absorb fatty acids/lipids.

section: Part 4: Small Intestine and Accessory Organs
stem: During "Segmentation" in the small intestine, what is the primary physiological goal?

choices.A: Rapid propulsion of food toward the large intestine.
choices.B: Mixing chyme with digestive secretions and mechanical breakdown of fat droplets.

rationale: Segmentation involves nonadjacent segments contracting/relaxing to mix food and slow its propulsion.

section: Part 4: Small Intestine and Accessory Organs
stem: Which enzyme is a "Brush border enzyme" used for the final stage of carbohydrate digestion?
rationale: Lactase, maltase, and sucrase are brush border enzymes that break disaccharides into monosaccharides.

section: Part 4: Small Intestine and Accessory Organs
stem: A patient is diagnosed with an infection of the "Kupffer cells." In which organ are these cells located?
rationale: Kupffer cells (hepatic macrophages) are located in the liver sinusoids.

section: Part 4: Small Intestine and Accessory Organs
stem: A nurse is teaching a student about the "Portal Triad." Which three structures are found at the corner of each liver lobule?

choices.A: Central vein, Hepatic artery, Bile duct.
choices.B: Branch of hepatic artery, Branch of hepatic portal vein, Bile duct.
choices.C: Hepatic vein, Cystic duct, Portal vein.
choices.D: Left hepatic duct, Right hepatic duct, Common hepatic duct.

rationale: The portal triad consists of a branch of the hepatic artery, a branch of the hepatic portal vein, and a bile duct.

section: Part 4: Small Intestine and Accessory Organs
stem: Bile salts are essential for which process?
rationale: Bile salts emulsify fat, breaking it into small droplets for lipase action.

section: Part 4: Small Intestine and Accessory Organs
stem: A patient’s bile duct is blocked by a stone. The nurse knows that the common bile duct (CBD) is formed by the union of which two ducts?

choices.B: Common hepatic duct and cystic duct.
choices.D: Common hepatic duct and pancreatic duct.

rationale: The common hepatic duct (CHD) is joined by the cystic duct to form the common bile duct (CBD).

section: Part 4: Small Intestine and Accessory Organs
stem: The "Ampulla of Vater" (hepatopancreatic ampulla) opens into which part of the GI tract?
rationale: The ampulla opens into the 2nd part of the duodenum at the major duodenal papilla.

section: Part 4: Small Intestine and Accessory Organs
stem: A patient is diagnosed with "Pancreatitis." The nurse knows the exocrine function of the pancreas involves "Acini" that produce:
rationale: Acini are clusters of secretory cells that produce pancreatic juice/proenzymes (exocrine function).

section: Part 4: Small Intestine and Accessory Organs
stem: Which hormone stimulates the pancreas to secrete a juice rich in bicarbonate ions?
rationale: Secretin increases the output of pancreatic juice rich in bicarbonate ions.

section: Part 4: Small Intestine and Accessory Organs
stem: What is the "Enterohepatic circulation"?

choices.A: The movement of food through the small intestine.
choices.B: The recycling of bile salts from the ileum back to the liver via the portal vein.
choices.C: The drainage of blood from the liver into the inferior vena cava.
choices.D: The secretion of hormones from the duodenum to the pancreas.

rationale: 95% of bile salts are reabsorbed in the ileum and returned to the liver via the portal vein. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Part 5: Large Intestine and Nutrient Absorption

section: Part 5: Large Intestine and Nutrient Absorption
stem: A patient is scheduled for an "Appendectomy." The nurse knows the appendix is attached to which part of the large intestine?
rationale: The appendix is a mass of lymphoid tissue attached to the cecum.

section: Part 5: Large Intestine and Nutrient Absorption
stem: While reviewing the anatomy of the large intestine, the nurse identifies "Teniae coli." What are these?

choices.A: Pocketlike sacs in the colon wall.
choices.C: Three bands of longitudinal smooth muscle.
choices.D: Permanent circular folds of the mucosa.

rationale: Teniae coli are three bands of longitudinal smooth muscle in the muscularis.

section: Part 5: Large Intestine and Nutrient Absorption
stem: A patient reports pain in the "left colic flexure." Where is this located?

choices.A: Between the cecum and ascending colon.
choices.B: Between the ascending and transverse colon.
choices.C: Between the transverse and descending colon.
choices.D: Between the descending and sigmoid colon.

rationale: The left colic (splenic) flexure is the turn between the transverse and descending colon.

section: Part 5: Large Intestine and Nutrient Absorption
stem: The nurse explains to a patient that "bacterial flora" in the large intestine are beneficial because they:

choices.B: Synthesize B complex vitamins and Vitamin K.
choices.C: Secrete brush border enzymes for protein digestion.

rationale: Resident bacteria synthesize B-complex vitamins and Vitamin K.

section: Part 5: Large Intestine and Nutrient Absorption
stem: During the defecation reflex, which event is under voluntary control?

choices.C: Relaxation of the internal anal sphincter.
choices.D: Relaxation of the external anal sphincter.

rationale: The external anal sphincter is composed of skeletal muscle and is under voluntary control.

section: Part 5: Large Intestine and Nutrient Absorption
stem: Which nutrient requires "cotransport with sodium ions" for absorption in the small intestine?
rationale: Glucose and galactose are absorbed via cotransport with sodium ions.

section: Part 5: Large Intestine and Nutrient Absorption
stem: A patient has a condition that reduces "Pancreatic Lipase" secretion. Which digestive process will be impaired?

choices.B: Breakdown of triglycerides into fatty acids and monoglycerides.
choices.C: Breakdown of proteins into amino acids.
choices.D: Breakdown of nucleic acids into nucleotides.

rationale: Pancreatic lipase breaks lipids (fats) into fatty acids and glycerol/monoglycerides.

section: Part 5: Large Intestine and Nutrient Absorption
stem: How are "Chylomicrons" transported away from the intestinal mucosa?

choices.A: Via the hepatic portal vein to the liver.
choices.B: Via the capillaries to the systemic circulation.
choices.C: Via the lacteals and the lymphatic system.
choices.D: Via the bile duct to the gallbladder.

rationale: Chylomicrons enter lacteals and are carried away in lymph.

section: Part 5: Large Intestine and Nutrient Absorption
stem: A patient has an injury below the "Pectinate line" in the anal canal. The nurse should assess for:

choices.B: Sharp somatic pain, as the region is sensitive to pain.

rationale: The region inferior to the pectinate line is innervated by somatic nerves and is sensitive to pain.

section: Part 5: Large Intestine and Nutrient Absorption
stem: What is the primary function of the "Haustra" in the large intestine?

choices.A: Increasing surface area for nutrient absorption.
choices.B: Pocketlike sacs that facilitate slow segmental movement.

rationale: Haustra are pocketlike sacs caused by the tone of teniae coli; haustral contractions provide slow segmental movement. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Part 6: Physical Assessment and Clinical Correlation

section: Part 6: Physical Assessment and Clinical Correlation
stem: A nurse is preparing to perform a physical assessment of a patient's abdomen. In what order should the assessment techniques be performed?
rationale: Auscultation should be performed after inspection and before percussion/palpation to avoid inducing changes in bowel sounds.

section: Part 6: Physical Assessment and Clinical Correlation
stem: During inspection, the nurse notes "Caput medusae" (enlarged veins on the abdomen). This is a clinical sign of which condition?
rationale: Caput medusae is associated with portal hypertension.

section: Part 6: Physical Assessment and Clinical Correlation
stem: A patient reports sharp pain when the nurse rapidly removes their hand after deep palpation. What is the name of this finding?
rationale: Rebound tenderness is pain worsened on releasing pressure, suggesting peritoneal irritation (peritonitis).

section: Part 6: Physical Assessment and Clinical Correlation
stem: While percussing the abdomen, the nurse hears a "tympany" sound. Where is this sound typically heard?

choices.A: Over solid organs like the liver.
choices.C: Over air-filled sections of the stomach or intestine.

rationale: Tympany is the predominant sound heard over air-filled sections of the stomach/intestine.

section: Part 6: Physical Assessment and Clinical Correlation
stem: The nurse is assessing for "Ascites." Which test involves tapping one side of the abdomen and feeling for a wave transmission on the other side?
rationale: The fluid thrill test involves feeling for a palpable wave transmitted across the abdomen.

section: Part 6: Physical Assessment and Clinical Correlation
stem: A patient is suspected of having "Appendicitis." The nurse palpates the "Left Lower Quadrant" (LLQ), and the patient feels pain in the "Right Lower Quadrant" (RLQ). What is this sign called?
rationale: Rovsing’s sign is when palpation in the left iliac fossa produces pain in the right iliac fossa.

section: Part 6: Physical Assessment and Clinical Correlation
stem: A nurse is measuring the "Liver span" at the midclavicular line (MCL). What is the normal range?
rationale: The normal liver span at the MCL is 6–12 cm.

section: Part 6: Physical Assessment and Clinical Correlation
stem: During a general examination, the nurse notes "Koilonychia" (spooning of the nails). This finding is associated with which condition?
rationale: Koilonychia suggests chronic iron deficiency anemia.

section: Part 6: Physical Assessment and Clinical Correlation
stem: A patient has "Leukonychia" (whitened nail beds). The nurse knows this may be a sign of:
rationale: Leukonychia is associated with hypoalbuminemia or liver failure.

section: Part 6: Physical Assessment and Clinical Correlation
stem: While assessing the mouth, the nurse identifies a "Lingual frenulum." What is its function?

choices.B: Attachment of the tongue to the floor of the mouth.
choices.C: Separation of the nasopharynx from the oropharynx.

rationale: The lingual frenulum attaches the tongue to the floor of the mouth.

section: Part 6: Physical Assessment and Clinical Correlation
stem: A nurse is performing "Light palpation" on a patient’s abdomen. What is the standard depth for this technique?
rationale: Light palpation is performed to a depth of 1 cm.

section: Part 6: Physical Assessment and Clinical Correlation
stem: A patient presents with "Jaundice" (icterus). Where is the best place for the nurse to inspect for this sign?
rationale: Jaundice is best assessed in the sclera of the eyes.

section: Part 6: Physical Assessment and Clinical Correlation
stem: A patient is observed to have "Dupuytren’s contracture." This thickening of the palmar fascia is often associated with:
rationale: Dupuytren’s contracture is associated with excess alcohol intake or family history.

section: Part 6: Physical Assessment and Clinical Correlation
stem: When percussing the spleen, the nurse knows that "Splenomegaly" is typically only detected when the spleen enlarges to what degree?
rationale: Splenomegaly is detected when the spleen enlarges 3 times its normal size.

section: Part 6: Physical Assessment and Clinical Correlation
stem: A patient has "Hyperactive" bowel sounds. The nurse knows this might indicate:
rationale: Hyperactive bowel sounds (5-6 sounds in < 30 secs) can indicate early obstruction. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Part 7: Integrated Physiology and Regulation

section: Part 7: Integrated Physiology and Regulation
stem: Which nervous system is considered "self-contained" (intrinsic) and regulates GI motility and secretory activity?
rationale: The Enteric Nervous System (ENS) is the intrinsic nerve supply to the GI tract wall.

section: Part 7: Integrated Physiology and Regulation
stem: A patient is salivating at the smell of food. This is an example of which phase of gastric regulation?
rationale: The cephalic phase occurs before food enters the stomach, triggered by smell, taste, sight, or thought.

section: Part 7: Integrated Physiology and Regulation
stem: What is the "Migrating Motor Complex"?

choices.B: A pattern of peristaltic activity during fasting, stimulated by motilin.
choices.C: The movement of the bolus through the pharynx.

rationale: Motilin stimulates the migrating motor complex every 1.5–2 hours during fasting.

section: Part 7: Integrated Physiology and Regulation
stem: A patient is experiencing "Reverse peristalsis." This is a key physiological component of which process?
rationale: Vomiting involves reverse peristalsis in the small intestine.

section: Part 7: Integrated Physiology and Regulation
stem: Which hormone inhibits gastric gland secretion and gastric motility when the stomach is too empty or chyme is too fatty?
rationale: CCK and Secretin inhibit the stomach’s secretory activity and motility.

section: Part 7: Integrated Physiology and Regulation
stem: The "Round ligament" (ligamentum teres) of the liver is a remnant of which fetal structure?
rationale: The round ligament is the remnant of the fetal umbilical vein.

section: Part 7: Integrated Physiology and Regulation
stem: A patient has a deficiency in "Vitamin K." The nurse knows this will primarily affect the liver's ability to:
rationale: Vitamin K is essential for the synthesis of blood clotting factors in the liver.

section: Part 7: Integrated Physiology and Regulation
stem: Which digestive enzyme is responsible for breaking down nucleic acids?
rationale: Nucleases break down nucleic acids into nucleotides.

section: Part 7: Integrated Physiology and Regulation
stem: What is the role of "Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide" (VIP)?

choices.C: Stimulates buffer secretion and dilates intestinal capillaries.

rationale: VIP stimulates buffer secretion, dilates capillaries, and relaxes intestinal smooth muscle.

section: Part 7: Integrated Physiology and Regulation
stem: A patient's feces are observed to be a brown color. This is primarily due to:
rationale: Bile pigments are responsible for the brown color of feces.
